conclusion: To solve the problem of finding the electric field strength at the intersection of the diagonals of the square, we need to consider the contributions of each charge to the electric field at that point.
The electric field due to a point charge q at a distance r is given by: E = kq/r^2 where k is the Coulomb constant.
Charge +q at A, Charge +q at B, Charge -q at C, Charge -q at D.
The side length of the square is L. The intersection of the diagonals of the square is the center of the square.

premise: The side length of the square is L.
conclusion: The distance from any vertex to the center of the square is r = L/sqrt(2).

premise: Charge +q at A, distance r = L/sqrt(2).
conclusion: Electric field due to +q at A at the center is E_A = 2kq/L^2.

premise: Charge +q at B, distance r = L/sqrt(2).
conclusion: Electric field due to +q at B at the center is E_B = 2kq/L^2.

premise: Charge -q at C, distance r = L/sqrt(2).
conclusion: Electric field due to -q at C at the center is E_C = -2kq/L^2.

premise: Charge -q at D, distance r = L/sqrt(2).
conclusion: Electric field due to -q at D at the center is E_D = -2kq/L^2.

premise: Electric fields E_A and E_C are in the same direction (along AC), and E_B and E_D are in the same direction (along BD).
conclusion: The total electric field at the center is the vector sum of the electric fields due to each charge.

premise: The electric fields E_A and E_B will add up, and E_C and E_D will add up in the opposite direction.
conclusion: The net electric field is zero.

premise: The electric fields due to the charges +q at A and B will cancel out the electric fields due to the charges -q at C and D in the direction perpendicular to the diagonals.
conclusion: The net electric field is zero.
